;中国的科学家已经开发出一种将折纸变成可穿戴设备和软机器人的方法涂上液态金属。

;

;涂有金属的纸可以像往常一样折叠，但通过金属的附加特性得到增强，例如可调刚度以及导热和导电的能力。它允许通过电力、温度变化或磁铁控制 3D 纸结构。

;

;“这种简便的方法为可穿戴测试平台和柔性设备以及软机器人提供了新的材料选择，”该团队来自清华大学、北京航空航天大学和中国科学院的研究人员在周五发表在同行评审期刊 Cell Reports Physical Science 上的一篇文章中写道。

;

;液态金属的一个常见例子是汞，一种有毒的银-在室温下呈液态的白色金属。它在 -39C (-38F) 左右冻结成软固体。

;

;在这项研究中，该团队使用了两种无毒液态金属合金 eGaIn（熔点为 15.5C）和 BiInS（熔点为熔点为 62C。

;

;科学家们发现，由于液态金属的表面张力极高，因此很难将液态金属粘在纸、塑料、布甚至人体皮肤等表面上，一些人已经尝试使用粘合剂。但研究人员表示，添加第三种材料可能会削弱产品的电气、热学或机械性能。

;

;中国团队首先将液态金属涂在硅胶印模上，然后用力摩擦印模，使之成为可能纸，以便金属液滴可以有效地结合到纸上。

;

;“这是计算的未来”：我们试用了 Apple 的 3,499 美元 Vision Pro 耳机

;

;科学家表明，金属涂层与未涂布纸一样，纸仍然可以折叠成不同的形状，例如起重机和可折叠的盒子。

;

;他们还将经过处理的纸折叠成类似弹簧的形状。由于液态金属增强剂的自粘能力，弹簧保持在其最大压缩状态，并可以在需要时拉伸到所需的长度或高度。

;

;金属可以通过冷却和回流凝固重新加热后恢复到原来的状态。科学家们在研究中让它重 50 克（1.8 盎司），显示出它作为多功能智能材料的潜力。

;

;主要作者、清华大学生物医学工程系博士后袁波北京大学表示，液态金属涂层可以将常用材料变成耐用的智能电子设备。

;

;“机器人抓手等设备通常由压缩空气或热量提供动力，并使用定制材料制造，”Yuan 说。 “现在我们可以用纸来制作它们。

;

;“当我们用电为金属夹纸器供电时，它会膨胀。没有电，它会收紧以拿起物品。物品移动到目的地后，抓手再次通电以释放物体。

;

;“我们还可以在皮肤上创建电路来监测手指运动、心脏活动和体温，”她

;

;中国纳米平台“航母”为癌症患者送药

;

;她说这种涂层价格实惠，只需要一层薄薄的金属，固化和剥离后可以回收利用

;

;Yuan 补充说，该团队将致力于防止液态金属涂层因触摸而熔化，并将其应用扩展到更多表面，例如其他金属和陶瓷。

;总理 Anthony Albanese 最近的越南之行是对澳大利亚与东南亚国家关系的认可就其自身而言，这个国家很重要——而不仅仅是它如何将澳大利亚与美国和中国的更广泛关系联系起来。

;

;因此，令人惊讶的是，对一个中等强国的国事访问执行得很好该地区的“战略伙伴关系”升级为“全面战略伙伴关系”，但未能成为实质性的头条新闻，也未能引起公众的想象。

;

;澳大利亚人需要看到这种增强区域伙伴关系（例如与越南的伙伴关系）具有重大利益，对澳大利亚的未来具有影响。

;

;澳大利亚和越南因越南法式越南糕、啤酒和对中国的共同担忧而联系在一起

;

;;

;这不是澳大利亚总理首次对越南进行双边访问。最近一次是斯科特·莫里森 (Scott Morrison) 于 2019 年的访问。但这次事件引起了特别的共鸣。

;

;今年是澳大利亚和越南建交 50 周年。当然，由于澳大利亚卷入了越南战争（在那里被称为“美国战争”），这是一个特别重要的时刻。

;

;在战争期间，有超过 60,000 名澳大利亚人被部署到该国，有 523 人死亡。这场战争及其起诉手段——尤其是征兵——成为澳大利亚国内两极分化的热点。

;

;战争给越南本身造成的代价是无法估量的。

;

;澳大利亚致力于战争从 1970 年底开始逐渐平息，最后一批澳大利亚军队于 1972 年 12 月返回家园，惠特拉姆政府当选后不久。澳大利亚的参与在一个月后正式结束。

;

;战后的几十年对越南来说极其艰难，因为它在国际孤立，尤其是美国孤立的情况下重建了自己。大量难民逃离了新的共产主义政权的专制统治，其中许多人在澳大利亚建立了强大而充满活力的社区。;

;1986 年，越南共产党宣布了大美改革，以将国家从一个高度发达的国家转变为以国家所有制为基础的中央集权经济是市场社会主义的一种形式。这开始了越南在经济和政治上向世界开放的进程。

;

;在随后的几年中，澳大利亚两党一直在努力巩固与越南在经济和国防协议方面的关系。

;

;越南寻找非俄罗斯武器的美国选择出现

;

;2009 年越南共产党总书记农德孟访问澳大利亚期间，两国关系升级为“全面合作伙伴关系”合伙”。 2018 年，为纪念两国建交 45 周年，两国进一步升级为“战略伙伴关系”。

;

;加强两国之间的联系具有明显的经济和外交利益。根据外交和贸易部的数据，在过去二十年中，两国之间的贸易平均每年增长 8.6%。

;

;但莫里森政府对越南的态度明显受到了

;

;莫里森在访问期间大肆宣扬贸易增长，但在他的政府外交政策框架内，很明显，相对而言，这种关系只是主要游戏的附属品：澳大利亚的未来与美国息息相关。

;

;

;

;自当选以来，奥尔巴尼政府就表明了重建和修复地区关系的决心。虽然这包括缓和最近与中国的紧张局势，但也包括加强与越南、马来西亚、印度尼西亚等国家的合作。

;

;政府的做法并没有否认澳大利亚正在进行的与美国的国防和政治关系，远非对中国在该地区的定位持被动态度。 Albanese 政府对 Aukus 的坚定承诺充分说明了这一点。

;

;但人们认识到，近年来澳大利亚外交政策的压倒性重视已经削弱了澳大利亚与这些中型地区的关系的重要性同样寻求适应亚太地区不断变化的关系和力量平衡的国家。

;

;正如最近的一份总理声明所述，加强澳大利亚与越南的关系是澳大利亚政府战略的重要组成部分。决心重建澳大利亚与东南亚国家的联系。

;

;越南最近经历了自己的经济困境。它非常依赖澳大利亚的煤炭发电，短期内这种情况可能会持续下去。它的政府是专制的。在讨论两国关系时不应忽视这一点。

;

;但越南是一个充满活力的国家，其经济一直处于上升期。它还拥有越来越熟练的年轻人口，并显示出自己与全球的联系。

;

;东南亚向澳大利亚展示了平衡美国衰落和中国崛起的方式

;

;澳大利亚是一个国家日益融入该地区并探索可再生能源的新经济机会。 Albanese 在河内签署的协议中有一项价值 1.05 亿美元的一揽子计划，旨在帮助越南实现经济脱碳。

;

;澳大利亚也有大量具有越南血统的公民，他们与越南有着持久的家庭和经济联系。目前的贸易和教育交流是互惠互利的，而且还在不断发展。

;

;所有这一切都发生在两个在人们记忆中处于战争状态的国家之间。

;

;越南的经历战争应该提醒所有澳大利亚人跟随美国追求其外交政策野心而不顾自己的危险。目前与越南的关系表明澳大利亚可以如何以自己的方式行事。

;

;利亚姆·伯恩 (Liam Byrne) 是墨尔本大学历史与哲学研究学院的荣誉院士。本文首发于.

;美国前总统唐纳德·特朗普因与司法部有关的联邦指控被起诉对他处理机密文件的调查，一份未密封的起诉书显示他有一名共同被告——他的助手 Walt Nauta。

;

;Nauta 被控六项罪名，包括串谋妨碍司法公正，一份文件或记录，以及虚假陈述和陈述。

;

;检察官声称，特朗普指示诺塔“移动文件箱，以防止特朗普的律师、联邦调查局和大陪审团发现它们”。

;< p>;他们声称特朗普和诺塔“向 FBI 隐藏、隐瞒和掩盖了特朗普在海湖庄园俱乐部继续持有机密文件的事实”。

;

;诺塔长期以来一直特朗普的私人助理，曾担任白宫贴身男仆，这一角色包括担任总统的私人助理、信使和跑腿员。

;

;纽约杂志的情报员报道说，诺塔是特朗普的“健怡可乐贴身男仆” ”，每当特朗普在白宫椭圆形办公室需要苏打水时，他都会为他送上苏打水。

;

;

;据《华盛顿邮报》报道，诺塔是六个兄弟姐妹之一，在 2001 年加入海军之前在西太平洋的美国岛屿关岛长大。在成为贴身男仆之前，他曾在白宫食堂工作。

;

;唐纳德特朗普新办公室的细目分类。他把健怡可乐藏起来了吗？

;

;

;《纽约时报》去年报道称，安全摄像头拍到诺塔从仓库搬箱子在司法部传唤特朗普之前和之后，海湖庄园的房间。

;

;当时，《泰晤士报》援引三名知情人士的话说，有人看到 Nauta 在安全摄像头上移动箱子。一位消息人士告诉《纽约时报》，联邦调查局还在 2022 年 8 月根据搜查令授权搜查海湖庄园之前采访了 Nauta。

;Nauta 的律师没有立即回应 Insider 的置评请求。

; Sat, 10 Jun 2023 08:20:02 +0800 For heat warnings to work, Hong Kong must have one clear, integrated systemhttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3223165/heat-warnings-work-hong-kong-must-have-one-clear-integrated-system?utm_source=rss_feed

;劳工处上个月推出香港新的工人热应激警告系统，是该市管理突发卫生事件和气候变化灾害风险的良好开端。这是因为研究表明香港的温度、发病率和死亡率之间存在密切关联。

;

;该预警系统使用香港热指数作为基准，该指数考虑了温度、湿度、风速和太阳辐射.

;

;但需要解决的问题是，如何将这个新系统与香港天文台现有的高温天气警报相结合，以简化香港针对高温风险的健康灾害警报系统。台风及暴雨警报系统已成功应用于工人。

;

;文章撰稿人之一陈慧娴于2014年与天文台合作研究及制定高温指数，利用住院及2007 年至 2011 年的热应激数据，以评估高温、高湿度、慢风和强太阳辐射对健康的影响。同年，天文台推出两级高温天气警告。

;

;第一级由高温指数 29.5 触发，当高温指数达到 30.5 时发出第二级警告。这些阈值是有科学依据的——在 29.5 时，超额住院率开始回升，在 30 后增加得更快，到 30.5 时，达到了一个令人担忧的水平。

;

;提前警告给了公众一个合理的提前时间以保护自己免受热应激增加的健康风险。

;

;相比之下，新的三层工作热应激警告将琥珀色、红色和黑色的阈值设置为热指数读数 30、32 和34——看起来太保守了。这尤其是因为户外工作者比一般人更容易受到天气的影响。

;

;5 月 22 日，当天文台向公众发出二级「酷热天气」警告时，劳工处并没有甚至对工作中的热应激发出最低的黄色警报。

;

;在一年中最热的一天 5 月 30 日，在“酷热天气”警告生效近 30 小时后发布了黄色警报，以及天文台在其新推出的「特别天气提示」下首次发出温度达到 35 摄氏度时的警报后 45 分钟。

;

;新警报系统的科学基础提高了透明度工作中的热应激可以提高人们对警报的理解及其效率。此外，拥有两个如此相似的警告系统会使公众感到困惑。鉴于简单明了的风险沟通很重要，应探索将这两个系统整合。

;

;此外，与台风和暴雨警报下的直接工作指南不同，新警报系统下的这些指南非常复杂的。不应低估政策实施的一线挑战以及向社区有效宣传热应激健康风险的困难。

;

;除了拥有正确的政策、支持性的工作环境和雇主外，提高公众对热应激的认识高温带来的健康风险、他们可以对极端温度警告做出的反应以及通过社区教育增强人们照顾自己的能力同样重要。

;

;预警系统需要协调和规划才能发挥作用，并且各方齐心协力，确保达到健康保护目标至关重要。

;

;消除对香港工人高温警报的困惑

;

;除了保护外出工作人员外，我们还应关注学童有炎热夏季的户外体育活动、孕妇、老年人和生活在次优条件下（如细分单元）的人可能会过度暴露在极端温度下。

;

;与成人相比，儿童的产热效率更高出汗效率较低，因此适应温度变化的速度较慢。重要的是，儿童更容易脱水，因为他们会很快失去水分并且没有意识到充分补充水分。

;

;老年人也容易受到极端温度的影响，因为衰老会影响身体调节温度的能力，导致散热减少。

;

;研究表明，高龄和患有非传染性疾病的人患不良健康结果的风险更高，包括心血管和呼吸系统疾病以及意外伤害.在香港的炎热季节，高于 29 度（日平均气温）每升高 1 摄氏度，所有入院人数就会增加 4.5%，因意外伤害入院人数会增加 1.9%。

;

;当温度上升到同一阈值以上时，儿童呼吸道入院人数（例如哮喘患者）和老年人感染病入院人数（例如肺炎）开始增加。

;

;风险当温度升高超过 28.8 度时，2 型糖尿病患者因心脏病发作入院的比例也会增加，这凸显了那些已有疾病的人的脆弱性。随着气候变化导致更频繁和更严重的极端温度危害，这些健康影响将会恶化。

;

;随着香港努力减轻气候变化的影响，无论是极端温度、海平面上升还是更频繁和更严重的气候变化台风和风暴潮变强，在北京强调高质量发展的情况下，政府政策不应偏离科学和理性，或为了经济活动而忽视减少灾害风险。

;波兰一家大型鸡肉生产商敲响了中国的大门，8 年没有卖出据其中一位代表说，虽然单鼓槌，但希望永存。

;

;Wipasz 副销售总监 Rafat Koztowski 上个月第二次访问浙江省宁波市参加了中国-中东欧国家博览会暨国际消费品博览会该公司自2015年申请进口许可证以来，一直到中国。

;

;尚未克服中国严格的肉类和家禽进口规定以及农产品进口的曲折申请流程。

;

;“他们给出了乐观，他们给出了希望，但没有给出时间表，”科兹托夫斯基在最近一次与中国同行会面后说。

;

;“我们没有放弃，我们仍然需要尝试。中国是一个非常大的市场。”

;

;中欧和东欧国家（CEEC），又称中东欧，包括保加利亚、克罗地亚、捷克共和国、波兰和罗马尼亚等国家，以及阿尔巴尼亚、波斯尼亚和黑塞哥维那以及塞尔维亚。

;

;根据 4 月份与中国官员会晤后发表的一份声明，波兰政府表示已推动“中国改变对肉类和家禽的做法”。< /p>;

;尽管官方解除了禁令，但中国仍未恢复从多个曾经发现禽流感病例的国家进口禽肉。

;

;Wipasz是此次展会的400多家中东欧展商之一宁波世博会于 5 月 16 日至 20 日举行。

;

;中国官员表示，本届世博会比 2021 年举办的上届世博会规模扩大了 30%，但只有少数国家（包括波兰、匈牙利和斯洛伐克）派出官方贸易代表团或设立国家展位。

;

;其他国家政府表现出的热情不足反映了他们对在世界上最大的消费市场之一立足的期望很低，尽管努力激发活力，但该市场目前正在收缩

;

;4 月份中国进口总额同比下降 7.9% 至 2052.1 亿美元，3 月份下降 1.4%，原因是需求疲软和大宗商品价格下跌。

; p>;

;中东欧对华贸易逆差也在不断扩大，去年对华出口额下降4.9%，自中国进口额增长约13.8%。

;

;最新一季度贸易数据显示出好转迹象，一季度中国对中东欧出口同比增长10.3%，自这两个地区进口增长7.3%。

;

;但4 月份进口额下降 12.2%，保加利亚、捷克共和国、波兰、罗马尼亚和黑山的进口额仅有增长。

;

;“日益明显”的需求疲软令中国出口降温，放缓至 2023 年底

;

;去年，波兰、捷克共和国和匈牙利是中国在中东欧的主要贸易伙伴，占从这两个地区进口额的 59.6%。

;

;当北京提出建议时2012 年与中东欧国家建立合作机制，其目的之一是通过从两个地区进口更多商品来解决贸易不平衡问题。

;

;北京称该机制是成功的，因为两国之间的贸易这两个地区和中国自成立以来平均每年增长 8.1%，从该地区的进口平均每年增长 9.2%。

;

;但是，交易项目仍然有限。机械进口占去年中国从中东欧进口额的 72.5%，农产品仅占 2.2%。

;

;在 2021 年 2 月与中东欧同行的在线会议上，习近平主席承诺进一步提高进口的价值和种类。

;

;“中国打算在未来五年从中东欧国家进口超过 1700 亿美元的商品，”他说。

;

;“我们要加快中东欧国家农产品进入中国，推动中东欧国家未来5年对华农产品出口翻番。”

;

;不过，合作机制启动不久之后分崩离析——立陶宛在抱怨参与后经济利益微乎其微后退出。爱沙尼亚和拉脱维亚去年效仿，使 14 个欧洲国家留在该机制中。

;

;中国-中东欧国家合作特别代表姜瑜在 5 月 17 日宁波经贸博览会期间举行的学术会议上表示

;

;“两国合作正处于关键发展时期，我们要继往开来，向未来发展，”她说。< /p>;

;“我们必须适应关系中出现的情况，并继续探索新的合作机制。”

;

;俄罗斯去年入侵乌克兰改变了欧洲的安全担忧和优先事项。但是，尽管许多中欧和东欧国家对中国与俄罗斯的密切关系越来越怀疑，但布达佩斯和北京的关系却变得更加温暖。

;

;据报道，匈牙利是宁波世博会的“唯一主宾国”中国官方说法。也是唯一一个拥有国家展位的国家。

;

;率团访问宁波的匈牙利外交和贸易部长Peter Szijjarto在进博会上的讲话中表示，这将是一个错误。欧盟与中国竞争，考虑合作的好处。

;

;“我们匈牙利人不认为中国是风险或威胁，但我们确实认为中国是合作的国家带来了很多利润和利益，”他在谈到欧洲就中国战略和与美国的结盟程度展开的激烈辩论时说。

;

;布达佩斯表示，欧盟要对这一事件负部分责任。乌克兰战争，并在过去十年中因加强对民间社会的控制而受到欧盟的批评。

;

;在 2 月访问布达佩斯期间，中国最高外交官王毅表示，匈牙利是“一个很好的国家”。欧洲的朋友”。

;

;王补充说，匈牙利对中国的“友好态度”不仅有利于匈牙利人民，也符合中国和欧洲的共同利益。

;

;在世博会前访问北京时，Szijjarto 宣布匈牙利期待中国在其汽车行业投资 30 亿欧元（32 亿美元），外交部长秦刚告诉他“双边关系已进入历史上最好的时期”。< /p>;

;匈牙利去年获得了 76 亿美元与中国“一带一路”倡议相关的投资——超过任何其他国家——尽管中国对欧洲的投资下降了 22%，延续了多年的下降趋势。

; p>;

;一位研究欧洲的上海学者表示，在一些国家退出该机制以及乌克兰战争引发地缘政治紧张局势之后，北京可能会以不同方式对待该地区的国家。

;

;“一个明显的变化是，中国的外交政策已经回归到更加基于国家和问题，”她说，要求匿名。

;

;“并不是说该机制会被取消，但没有什么真正有意义的东西会通过它来完成，它只会作为一个象征来支持中国与这些地区建立关系的渴望。

;

;“我认为北京终于意识到，这实际上是不可能的，也没有真正意义尝试同时与这么多不同的国家打交道。它们的地缘政治重要性、地理位置以及与中国的贸易额差异太大。

;

;“有人可能会说这是回到起点，机制建立之前，但至少现在我们发现，我们不应该把希望寄托在这条前进的道路上。”

Pundits splithttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3223624/will-donald-trumps-federal-indictment-hurt-his-chances-winning-2024-us-presidential-race-pundits?utm_source=rss_feed

;对美国前总统唐纳德特朗普的历史性联邦起诉，共和党的领先者明年大选的候选人，对于他最近的法律纠纷将如何影响他从乔·拜登手中夺回白宫的机会，专家们意见不一。

;

;美国司法部公布了一项涉及 37 项重罪的全面起诉书，涉及周五对机密文件处理不当，包括指控特朗普描述了五角大楼的“攻击计划”并分享了与军事行动有关的机密地图。

;

;大部分指控是针对特朗普的，他与沃尔特一起被起诉前总统的助手和亲密顾问诺塔涉及“故意保留国防信息”。其他包括一项“串谋妨碍司法公正”罪名和另一项“腐败地隐瞒文件或记录”罪名。

;

;这是特朗普的第二起刑事案件，而且可能不是最后一起。明年 3 月，他将在纽约接受审判，案件涉及向一名色情女演员支付封口费。 Trump is also is under investigation for his role in the deadly January 6, 2021 attack on the Capitol by his supporters.

;

;Meanwhile, Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis, a Democrat, has been investigating allegations that Trump tried to convince Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger and the southeastern US state's governor, Brian Kemp, both Republicans, to deny that Biden won their state in the 2020 presidential election.

;

;And last month, a jury in federal court in Manhattan decided in a civil lawsuit that he must pay US$5 million in damages for sexually abusing former Elle magazine columnist E. Jean Carroll and then defaming her by branding her a liar.

;

;The accumulating legal actions against the former president inject an uncertain dynamic into the coming presidential election as the developments had not affected his standing as the Republican Party's front runner, although it remains to be seen how much the newly released evidence against Trump will sway public opinion.

;

;In a Quinnipiac poll conducted for five days ended May 22, Trump garnered 56 per cent compared with 25 per cent for Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, who declared his candidacy last month. That represented a doubling of Trump's lead against his main opponent in less than two months.

;

;Nikki Haley, a former US ambassador to the United Nations, Trump's vice-president Mike Pence and several others have also entered the race for the Republican nomination, all polling behind DeSantis.

;

;For Trump, bloated 2024 Republican race points to a 2016 redux

;

;As the field of candidates grows, Trump has used the cases and investigations he faces as fundraising tools, telling supporters that he is under attack and needs their help. Trump's campaign said in April that donations surged after he was indicted in New York.

;

;Todd Belt, a political-science professor at George Washington University, said the latest indictment was likely to boost Trump's polling further.

;

;“Donald Trump has been exceptional at turning bad news into good politics in terms of fundraising, and it allows him to claim victimhood, which he loves to do,” Belt said. “We saw pretty much unanimity of the voices of some of the highest-ranking members in the House of Representatives and Senate really rallying behind him.”

;

;Within minutes of Trump's announcement of the federal indictment, his 2024 team began pushing the news to raise funds for his presidential campaign, asking “hardworking patriots” to “SAVE AMERICA” and contribute amounts ranging from US$24 to US$3,300.

;

;Trump wrote a post declaring he had been indicted, saying that he “never thought it possible that such a thing could happen to a former president of the United States”, and that he was “AN INNOCENT MAN!”

;

;He then professed his innocence in a video and framed the indictment as a form of election interference by a Justice Department “weaponised” by the Biden administration.

;

;“They come after me because now we're leading in the polls again by a lot against Biden,” Trump said in the clip.

;

;“Our country is going to hell and they come after Donald Trump … We can't let this continue.”

;

;Fellow Republicans have so far stood by Trump, including House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, who has had a roller-coaster relationship with the former president.

;

;“Today is indeed a dark day for the United States of America. It is unconscionable for a president to indict the leading candidate opposing him,” McCarthy said in a statement.

;

;Trump caught on tape acknowledging he kept classified document on Iran: report

;

;“I, and every American who believes in the rule of law, stand with President Trump.”

;

;DeSantis echoed Trump's claims of a “weaponised” Justice Department, adding on Twitter that he would “excise political bias” if elected president.

;

;The Twitter account of Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee posted a repeated Trump slogan: “WITCH HUNT”.

;

;Special counsel Jack Smith, named by US Attorney General Merrick Garland, has been looking into a cache of classified documents that Trump stored at his Mar-a-Lago residence in Florida after leaving the White House. Garland brought Smith on to the case to deflect criticism that any charges brought against Trump were politically motivated.

;

;Biden was also found to have had classified documents from the time of his tenure as vice-president in his possession, in multiple troves both at his home in Delaware and at the Penn Biden Centre in Washington, giving Trump and his allies some degree of defence.

;

;Garland appointed a former US attorney as special counsel to investigate Biden's handling of the classified documents. The main difference in the two cases is that Biden officials alerted federal authorities to their improper placement.

;

;“Even though … the attempt to obstruct justice is very different than what Biden did, the Republicans can point to the fact even though it's not apples to apples, that Biden did it too,” Belt said. “That really gives them sort of the rationale to be dismissive and to call [Trump's indictment] politically motivated.”

;

;Not everyone agreed that Trump's latest indictment would boost his political standing in the coming primaries or the general election.

;

;Terry Haines, founder of Washington consultancy Pangaea Policy, said the action would likely further alienate anyone not in Trump's base.

;

;The indictment increases the already substantial likelihood that Trump won't again be president, increasing already substantial toxicity with independent and centrist voters,” Haines said in a research note. “It also increases the likelihood that Trump won't be the Republican nominee.”

;

;E. Jean Carroll seeks new damages from Trump over post-verdict statements

;

;“The other candidates – including his former vice-president [Mike Pence] and other prominent 2016 supporters – now will 'pack swarm' Trump … intensifying efforts to paint Trump as unfit for office even while they raise questions about the appropriateness of prosecuting a former president,” he added.

;

;William Banks, a professor emeritus of public administration and international affairs at Syracuse University, said the fact that Trump's polling numbers rose after the hush-money indictment in New York would make an uptick in the polls possible even while facing much more serious charges related to national security.

;

;However, while Trump's “most diehard supporters are always going to be supporters no matter what … some people who are on the margins, part of the 40 per cent that voted for him a couple of times, will tend to peel away”, he said.

;

;“These are charges that he's retained national security information and actually shared some of it with others that his golf course in a way that could be injurious to the United States,” Banks added. “And we've always taken very seriously threats to national security.”

;Two concepts have increasingly taken centre stage in geopolitical discussions around the European Union. The first is “strategic autonomy”, the second, “de-risking”.

;

;There was much fanfare around the first, following French President Emmanuel Macron's visit to China in April. It centred on the notion that Europe would rise above the fray of US-China tensions and embrace Macron's calls for an EU that puts European interests first and takes the side of neither the United States nor China.

;

;Such hopes were swiftly dashed. Russia's invasion of Ukraine has triggered in European countries – especially small and medium-sized former Soviet states – a heightened sense of concern over national security and collective European defiance.

;

;Many have come to painfully realise the costs of relying too heavily on Russia for oil and gas. This has given rise to the notion of de-risking – a vague term, invoked by European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, which broadly gestures at the need to reduce European dependence on foreign actors across strategically sensitive sectors while falling short of full decoupling.

;

;By de-risking, the EU should in theory seek to reduce overexposure to all external economies. However, for many politicians and bureaucrats in Europe, the risk primarily stems from Russia and China.

;

;This world view reflects the increasing strain in Sino-European relations. This has been amplified by the efforts of the US and its allies to curb China's technological progress and shore up security in the Indo-Pacific.

;

;Some might argue that the EU, as with the rest of the Old World, does not matter to China. To these people, attempts at improving relations are a waste of time. Instead, I would call doing so realistic.

;

;The EU matters greatly to China, for at least three reasons. First, the bloc serves as a critical counterweight against a US-led coalition that considers China its primary geopolitical competitor. Most European states prefer not to choose between their two biggest economic partners.

;

;Second, the EU is China's second-largest trading partner behind the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, with total trade in 2022 reaching nearly US$850 billion. As Beijing seeks to reboot the economy amid sluggish domestic consumption and high household debt, securing the confidence of foreign multinational firms and stabilising supply chains is of paramount importance.

;

;Third, the EU is a key pillar in Beijing's vision for a multipolar world order. European countries do not harbour a desire for hegemony. The EU's greatest asset lies in its ability to lead and shape institutional norms without seeking financial or geopolitical dominance.

;

;China's consumer recovery still bumpy as households keep purse strings tight

;

;Senior Chinese diplomats are well aware that Europe is too important to alienate. Even so, improving relations from the nadir of the Comprehensive Agreement on Investment collapsing two years ago requires concrete action and an understanding of European hearts and minds.

;

;Most European states have clearly staked out their stance on the Ukraine war. As German and Estonian representatives affirmed at the Shangri-La Dialogue, the price for peace in Ukraine cannot be Kyiv making vast concessions to Moscow as that would jeopardise the EU's core national security interests. A need to affirm solidarity and moral authority has meant that smaller states in particular are likely to stand up against Russian violations of Ukrainian territorial sovereignty.

;

;Having spoken to stakeholders throughout the EU, I am convinced European politicians genuinely prefer not to take sides between the US and China where possible.

;

;Trade with China and the transatlantic relationship are both highly significant. Yet, if the perception of China's support for Russia were to persist and should Europe conclude that a China-led coalition cannot help facilitate peace in Ukraine, the scales would tip in favour of the EU establishing more robust strategic and military ties with the US. In international relations, perception – not intent – is key.

;

;Also, European talk of de-risking reflects a growing wariness over the tenuous peace in the Indo-Pacific. Next year's US election could return to power an erratic, unhinged ultranationalist in Donald Trump, whose closest intraparty contender Ron DeSantis is a neoconservative also bent on containing China.

;

;Talk of war portends escalating tensions over the Taiwan Strait, where a recent near-collision between Chinese and American warships serves to illustrate how dangerously close the world is to a hot showdown between superpowers.

;

;De-risking through friend-shoring, near-shoring, stockpiling and cultivating home-grown resilience in relation to strategic minerals is thus in equal parts a response to the war in Ukraine and a pre-emption of worsening flare-ups in East Asia. The latter would put further pressure on the EU via sanctions, counter-sanctions and supply-chain disruptions.

;

;Finally, Beijing must do more to assuage the concerns of European businesses. A core feature of any healthy economy is its ability to convince investors and companies that there is much that will keep it going.

;

;Joerg Wuttke, the outgoing head of the European Union Chamber of Commerce in China, has expressed concerns over China's growth trajectory for the next one to two decades. Wuttke is no China-basher; he speaks with authority and much experience in the country. The more pessimistic that European firms are about China's economic prospects, the less likely direct investment will be.

;

;In contrast, those convinced China is again shifting into a pro-growth mindset – underpinned by strengthening intellectual property safeguards and the interests of private business – are likely to eschew the zero-sum rationale of recent years. Sino-European relations will remain fraught, but this is not a time for resignation.

;Former US president Donald Trump is facing 37 felony charges related to the mishandling of classified documents, according to an indictment unsealed on Friday that alleges that he described a Pentagon “plan of attack” and shared a classified map related to a military operation.

;The indictment marks the Justice Department's first official confirmation of a criminal case against Trump arising from the retention of hundreds of documents at his Florida home, Mar-a-Lago.

;

;The indictment accuses Trump of having improperly removed scores of boxes from the White House to take them to Mar-a-Lago, many of them containing classified information.

;

;It carries unmistakably grave legal consequences, including the possibility of prison if Trump's convicted.

;

;But it also has enormous political implications, potentially upending a Republican presidential primary that Trump had been dominating and testing anew the willingness of Republican voters and party leaders to stick with a now twice-indicted candidate who could face still more charges.

;

;And it sets the stage for a sensational trial centred on claims that a man once entrusted to safeguard the nation's most closely-guarded secrets wilfully, and illegally, hoarded sensitive national security information after leaving office.

;

;Trump's Republican rivals criticise 'weaponisation' of US Justice Department

;

;The case adds to deepening legal jeopardy for Trump, who has already been indicted in New York and faces additional investigations in Washington and Atlanta that also could lead to criminal charges.

;

;But among the various investigations he has faced, legal experts – as well as Trump's own aides – had long seen the Mar-a-Lago probe as the most perilous threat and the one most ripe for prosecution.

;

;Campaign aides had been bracing for the fallout since Trump's lawyers were notified that he was the target of the investigation, assuming it was not a matter of if charges would be brought, but when.

;

;Some capitals worry that Brussels is veering onto their turf by conflating trade policy with “national security” and in general.

;

;“National security means national security,” one western European diplomat said, a reminder that the EU has no domain over its members' individual policies in this area.

;

;An early-stage proposal for the new economic security strategy – which will not directly target China, but which has been drafted with it in mind – is due on June 20, having been first announced by von der Leyen during a speech on China at the end of March.

;

;At that time, she warned of the need to wean Europe off Chinese supplies of critical minerals, and to keep cutting-edge European technologies out of the hands of China's military.

;

;The policy will include outbound investment screening, which would restrict European firms from investing in some sectors of the Chinese economy.

;

;The concept has made western European capitals jittery about Brussels moving too close to Washington, where security has trumped economic rationale when it comes to Beijing, a second diplomat said.

;

;A third added that while Seibert presented “a good overall plan, we need to be careful not to mimic the American in their posture and their words.”

;

;“The overall response was pragmatic, we aren't interested in a gung ho approach to China,” said a fourth.

;

;The lukewarm response could set the tone for an EU leaders debate on China later this month, as the 27 top officials mull over an updated policy towards Beijing.

;

;EU racing to devise new China strategy with 'de-risking' at its core

;

;“It is evident from member states' reactions that she did not consult EU governments before rhetorically aligning with the Biden administration on this subject,” said David Kleimann, a visiting fellow at the Bruegel think tank in Brussels.

;

;“This is surprising, because limitations to outbound capital flows are subject to unanimity in the European Council. Moreover, member states have exclusive competence for national security matters,” he added.

;

;The von der Leyen camp is unfazed by the blowback and points to a series of trade weapons pointed at China that were unpopular with EU members initially, only to eventually pass into law.

;

;An anti-coercion instrument designed to tackle China's perceived economic bullying was formally agreed upon this week, less than two years after it was proposed. Initially, free market-minded member states had been extremely uncomfortable with the concept.

;

;Also, von der Leyen's supporters note, she has said that the national security elements of her de-risking proposal would be very limited, to specific tech industries like quantum computing, artificial intelligence and semiconductors.

;

;The vast majority of trade and investment is deemed unrisky, and would not be affected.

;

;Western Europe's anxiety has crept into other areas of EU-China relations as well.

;

;Some members are frustrated that Beijing was not consulted earlier about proposed EU sanctions on eight Chinese companies – some of which have bases in Hong Kong – for funnelling banned European goods to Russia's military.

;

;EU could agree to new sanctions on Chinese firms next week, diplomats say

;

;Relevant EU officials only met with Chinese interlocutors to explain why the firms had been targeted this week, according to a senior EU source, despite reaching out earlier to other countries in a similar position.

;

;“We don't need to tell them everything, but we need to stay engaged, I mean it is China,” said a western European diplomat about the delayed approach to Beijing. “We need to explain [things] to China – as always, it's more about respect than consent with them.”

;

;The measures, which have been negotiated for the past month, could be finalised as soon as Wednesday as part of a broader package of sanctions, mostly on Russia.

;

;China's ambassador to the EU, Fu Cong, has complained about the lack of consultation and suggested in a recent interview that if presented with evidence he could help close the loopholes through which hi-tech goods used in cruise missiles were being sold to Russia.

;

;Czech foreign minister calls for more united EU-US approach to China

;

;Not everyone shares anxieties over a sharper EU turn on China. Many member states from central and eastern Europe are very comfortable with a tougher approach and with greater alignment with the US.

;

;“What we see right now is that the western European capitals tend to regard China-related challenges primarily through the lens of economic security. This is the order of the day and the key discussion,” said Grzegorz Stec, an analyst of EU-China relations at the Mercator Institute for China Studies in Berlin.

;

;“In turn, central and eastern European capitals are closer to the [Ukraine] war, making the traditional security lens comparatively stronger. Beijing's relationship with Moscow impacts these countries' fundamental safety and brings in more geopolitical dynamics given that Nato and the US act as security guarantors in the region,” he added.

;Two lawyers defending Donald Trump on federal charges of illegally retaining classified documents quit the case on Friday and a former aide was charged as well in surprise developments one day after the former US president was indicted.

;

;Trump said on his Truth Social platform that his former military valet, Walt Nauta, had been charged in the case. Nauta went to work at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort after working in the Trump White House. It was unclear what his charges were.

;

;Nauta's lawyer, Stanley Woodward, declined to comment. A spokesperson for Special Counsel Jack Smith, who is leading the prosecution, could not be reached immediately.

;

;Nauta “served proudly with me in the White House, retired as Senior Chief, and then transitioned into private life as a personal aide”, Trump wrote on Truth Social.

;

;In an earlier post, Trump said he would be represented in the case by white collar defence lawyer Todd Blanche, who is representing him in a separate criminal case in Manhattan.

;

;Trump made that announcement after his lawyers John Rowley and Jim Trusty quit the case for reasons that were not immediately clear.

;

;“This morning we tendered our resignations as counsel to President Trump,” the two lawyers said in a statement. “It has been an honour to have spent the last year defending him, and we know he will be vindicated.”

;

;Trump faces seven criminal counts related to his treatment of sensitive government materials he took with him when he left the White House in January 2021, according to a source familiar with the matter. He is due to appear in the Florida court on Tuesday, a day before his 77th birthday.

;

;Trump's Republican rivals criticise 'weaponisation' of US Justice Department

;

;The indictment of a former US president on federal charges is unprecedented in American history and emerges at a time when Trump is the front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination next year.

;

;The case does not prevent Trump from campaigning or taking office if he were to win the November 2024 presidential election. Legal experts say there would be no basis to block his swearing-in even if he were convicted and sent to prison.

;

;Investigators seized roughly 13,000 documents from Trump's Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Florida, nearly a year ago. One hundred were marked as classified, even though one of Trump's lawyers had previously said all records with classified markings had been returned to the government.

;

;“I AM AN INNOCENT MAN!” Trump wrote on his Truth Social platform on Thursday after announcing he had been indicted.

;

;Trump has previously said he declassified those documents while president, but his lawyers have declined to make that argument in court filings.

;

;CNN reported on Friday that Trump said after leaving office that he had retained military information that he had not declassified. Those comments, captured on audio, could be a key piece of evidence in the case.

;

;US District Judge Aileen Cannon has been initially assigned to oversee the case, according to a separate source who was briefed on the matter. She could preside over the trial as well, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

;

;Cannon, appointed by Trump in 2019, made headlines last year when she decided in favour of the former US president at a pivotal stage of the case and was later reversed on appeal.

;

;'It's not my thing': Trump says he won't drop White House bid if convicted

;

;Cannon would determine, among other things, when a trial would take place and what Trump's sentence would be if he were found guilty.

;

;Trusty told CNN on Thursday that the charges include conspiracy, false statements, obstruction of justice, and illegally retaining classified documents under the Espionage Act.

;

;It is the second criminal case for Trump, who is due to go on trial in New York next March in a state case stemming from a hush-money payment to a porn star.

;

;If he wins the presidency again, Trump, as head of the federal government, would be in a position to derail the federal case, but not the state one in New York.

;

;Trump's legal woes have not dented his popularity with Republican voters, according to Reuters/Ipsos polling. His main Republican rivals have so far lined up behind him to criticise the case as politically motivated.

;

;Trump served as president from 2017 to 2021, and he has so far managed to weather controversies that might torpedo other politicians. He describes himself as the victim of a witch hunt and accuses the Justice Department of partisan bias.

;

;Special Counsel Smith, who is heading the investigation, is leading a second criminal probe into efforts by Trump and his allies to overturn his 2020 election loss to President Joe Biden, a Democrat. Smith has been given a degree of independence from Justice Department leadership to pursue the politically sensitive cases.

;

;President Joe Biden found out about the indictment like everyone else and did not have advance knowledge of it, the White House said on Friday.

;

;Trump caught on tape acknowledging he kept classified document on Iran: report

;

;Trump also faces a separate criminal probe in Georgia related to efforts to overturn his loss to Biden in that state.

;

;Smith convened grand juries in both Washington and Miami to hear evidence, but has opted to bring the case in the politically competitive state of Florida, rather than the US capital, where any jury would likely be heavily Democratic.

;

;Under federal law, defendants have a right to be charged where the activity in question took place. A Florida prosecution, legal experts say, could head off a drawn-out legal challenge from Trump's team over the proper venue.

;

;The Republican state-by-state presidential nominating contest kicks off early next year, and the party is due to choose its nominee for the November 2024 election in July of that year.
